story:
UPDATE!

Vote On Our Official Show Name!!

Now that you have learned about what our show's concept is and what our mission is, we invite you to be part of the interaction of the show!
YOU now get a chance to help us vote on what the official name of the show is!
Click the bit.ly link below and participate in our voting strategy! You get to choose a few, and then rank your top picks from #1-#5!

https://bit.ly/2PZPxsv

-------------------------

Ebyssian Productions
Authenticity Through Humanity TV Show Project

Have you ever felt like your story isn't being told? Like you don't see yourself reflected in the characters you see on screen? That's what inspired Dan Moen to start Ebyssian Productions! We have developed a grassroots series that centers around an interracial family who own a bubble tea shop in the Metro Detroit area during the Covid-19 Pandemic. And we need your help!

When the pandemic hit in 2020, Dan noticed the lack of representation and alienation of different minorities and marginalized communities, both in film and television, and felt it became more amplified, especially Asian representation, both on screen and in production. Inspired by the Netflix show, Kim’s Convenience, Dan started to write up his own story. From there, he took to social media to pitched the idea of a show with good Asian representation both on screen and off funded through grassroots and community organizing. 

Dan connected with other highly talented team members, most from Michigan, and formed an incredible production team that consists predominantly of BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, People of Color) individuals and members of LGBTQ+ community. The project has grown to include a variety of intersectional identities and the complexities these identities have on the lives of the characters. 

Show Synopsis

Our ultimate goal is to develop a 6 episode season, starting with the pilot. Each episode will focus on the 'day in the life' of our main family, the Arbors. The Arbors are a bi-racial family with black and Filipino decent living in the city of Detroit.

  • Edith Arbor has an entrepreneurial spirit and hails from the Visayas region of the Philippines. She's juggling being a mother, an immigrant, and also trying to keep the family business a float with her husband and business partner, James. She moved to Michigan after marrying James and worked in a hospital as a nurse. Overtime, she and James decided to open a bubble tea shop and she soon left nursing to pursue her passion. She's extremely supportive of her children and wants them to peruse something they are passionate about. Sometimes, she struggles with relating to her children especially mental health wise.
  • James Arbor is an African-American veteran who fought in the Middle East and is currently dealing with undiagnosed PTSD and anxiety. Much of this is stemmed from both fighting for a country he is constantly alienated in and dealing with the 2020 pandemic.  He's also very hesitant with taking major financial risks with the family business as any entrepreneur would be. Originally working in the automotive industry, James decided to pursue his passion as well of opening a family run business and soon left the automotive field. James' fellow veteran friend, Traverse, constantly butt-heads on world views and beliefs, but manage to be civil.
     
  • Louis Arbor is the oldest son. He works at a hospital in the business and finances department. Graduated with a technical writing degree from the University of Michigan, he's pursuing his passion, but ultimately wants to become a higher executive. Louis is also gay, but is not out and in a private secret relationship with his partner of a few years, Dr. Asa Coen. Louis also leans heavily conservative, providing more perspective as communities are not monoliths. His partner and Louis constantly debate over political matters, but are able to respect each other as well.
     
  • Visaya Ann Arbor is the middle daughter. She is currently attending Wayne State University pursuing a degree in counseling and psychology. She works at the family shop in between school and on the weekends. She tries to understand people through her studies, but struggles oftentimes to empathize, which is key for her field. Studying and working so much has given her a lot of stress and anxiety and she struggles with self-acceptance, even though her grades are excellent. Visaya tries to remain neutral regarding politics, and tries focus on her studies, although she would lean left.
     
  • Mindelina Arbor is the youngest child in the Arbor family. She is still attending high school and is not planning on attending college. Her passion is to be in media and dreams of being an influencer.  However, she deals with massive stage fright and oftentimes shuts down if people are watching her live. When she is alone, however, she feels confident and can express herself. Mindelina also has ADHD and juggling around high school, social media, and trying to keep up with the latest trends on TikTok, oftentimes shuts her down as well where every project is important, so no project is important, and this causes an endless cycle for her. Mindelina is also very vocal when it comes to racism and hatred. She's the opposite to her brother, Louis. 


They own a bubble tea shop in the fictional suburb of Verona Hills in the fictional county of Motorlake. Motorlake is located south of Oakland and Macomb, north of Wayne County and stretches from Livingston to Lake St. Clair. The county executive is Ruth Dovetail, a Native American woman with Odawa ancestry and the mayor of Verona Hills is a Muslim woman of South Asian heritage. There are several nearby suburbs, cities, and towns with the same name, as historically, many of these were part of the same town; Verona Woods, Verona Heights,  and Veronaopolis. 

  • Bahay Kubo Tea is the name of the Arbor's boba tea shop business. It has been struggling during the 2020 pandemic and the family is trying to make ends meet. The name Bahay Kubo is what the traditional homes in the Philippines are called, also known as nipa huts, so the bubble tea shop has become a 2nd home for the family and the community. Decorated with Detroit memorabilia and fusion of traditional Filipino decor, the shop welcomes the community in and has become a relatively known shop in the area over time.  One could tell this is family run as they proudly show their family photos on their walls behind the counter as well as other memories. The shop has been in business for about three years, but the pandemic hit their finances hard.


The show has many characters from a wide range of intersectional identities, classes, ethnicities, and backgrounds and will explore mental health as well as how the pandemic, rise of racial hate crimes, social media, politics, and technology have impacted many of the communities from the perspective of BIPoC and other marginalized communities.

  • Zahira is one of Visayas close friends and is also attending Wayne State University to peruse a career in psychology. Her dream is to be a therapist or a psychologist and to give back to her community in Dearborn. Zahira is Muslim. She's also a major activist and is on the board of multiple non-profit organizations. Zahira's belief is get involved, because that makes change. In her down time, she loves anime, video games, and absolutely loves to cosplay and is part of a few D&D campaigns. She's also a huge fan of the Ebyssian Elves, a fictional fantasy franchise that focuses on elves of color.  Zahira internally however, struggles with depression and anxiety being so busy. She also has a medical condition with her digestive track that causes her a great deal of stress. She struggles to say 'no' to opportunities, and can work herself into mental overload.
     
  • Chinoden Gonzales-Mishimikinaak is a good friend to Louis and Asa. He is attending Oakland University and focusing on a career in political science. His dream is to be in politics and run for governor of Michigan, Senate, or Congress. He grew up in Detroit, and much of his culture and family are on the "rez". This has given him an internal identity crisis coming from two cultures of being Mexican American, as well as Native American, Ojibway. Chinoden struggles a lot with imposter syndrome and feels a disconnect to his heritage and culture.  Chinoden is also very much involved in political movements and oftentimes debates Louis. Louis, Asa, and Chinoden all met through the same dance crew, as this is how they handle much of their stress and anxiety.
    ​
  • Dr. Asa Coen is Louis Arbor's boyfriend. They have been together for about a year. Asa comes from an Iberian Sephardic Jewish background. Asa grew up very poor with his parents in a small apartment.  When he was young, Asa came down with a serious health risk that pushed him into pursuing medical as a career choice. He loves to bake, but is terrible with following baking directions, and oftentimes experiments with weird concoctions that it makes Louis queasy. His dream was to open a pastry shop, but his life at the hospital has been so busy and rampant that he doesn’t have a lot of time to stop. With the rise of covid cases, he works even more hours which prolongs his deep passions. Asa also struggles with deep depression internally, although he rarely allows others to see it, other than Louis, and also struggles with ADHD. He takes a lot of this stress out in dance with his partner. He’s been nicknamed, “The Dancing Doctor” at his work.

  • Claire Houghton is the the wife of Traverse Houghton and mother to Dale Houghton. Claire and Traverse are old friends to the Arbors as Traverse and James fought in the Middle East together. Claire is a witty and open woman. Growing up, Claire marched in the 1960s for anti-war demonstrations and protests. She comes from a long line of suffragettes, hippies, and grew up middle class. Although Claire is disheartened by racism, she fails to see how systematic racism impacts her and her friends. Internally, she struggles with accepting her privilege and oftentimes alienates many of those she holds dear especially with her belief of 'not seeing color' as well as using her youth activism to prove herself. She's open to learning, but very much comes off as tone deaf.
  • Traverse Houghton is a very deep conservative Republican. He grew up in a very small town and was taught at a young age about American loyalty, values, and morals. Traverse has deeply internalized this over the years and strongly believes that success is solely dependent on one's own ambition, not the job of the government, and one's own failures is solely their own. When his son Dale came out as Trans-male, Traverse battled internally as well as externally to accept his son for who he is. Since Dale was a baby, Traverse cherished Dale as his dead name and identity Fern, his daughter. Today, Traverse encounters constant conflicts with Dale and others in the community, especially over politics. Traverse feels he doesn't know his child anymore.
     
  • Dale Houghton is the adoptive son of Claire and Traverse. Dale was born in China and grew up in the suburbs. Internally, Dale battles being a trans-cultural and trans-national adoptee. He often has arguments with Louis as Louis still wants to call him by his dead name, Fern, and identities (she/her). Dale only within the last year or so has come out as trans-male. Despite the struggles, Dale put his heart and soul into social media as he has documented his story there and has become an influencer.  Dale his experience and his platform to empower others especially within the transgender communities, adoptee communities, Asian communities, and people of color. Although Dale comes off as put-together and empowered, Dale deals with significant depression and anxiety which causes Dale to go for days without updates on his social platforms, and finds confort in doing nothing.

 

  • Ichika and Xiong  Ichika was born and raised in southern California and met her husband when he was working in Los Angeles. Xiong is from Hawai'i and moved to Los Angeles to work. She tends to be quite a socialite and loves spending time with the communities. She's a third generation Japanese American. She doesn’t speak Japanese, and although raised in a Japanese family, she feels a disconnect to the motherland and her own culture. Ichika and Xiong opened a franchise bubble tea company and has grown pretty successful over the years. Their bubble tea shop has a very classy and upscale vibe with multiple private rooms for karaoke and banquet rooms for big parties. Xiong worked as an engineer for the automotive industry for many years until deciding to start the shop's franchise. While working for the automotive industry, Xiong and Ichika invested funds into a small shop and quickly grew until the big company today. Despite these successes, Xiong and Ichika are struggling with their marriage as they have slowly become more business partners than a loving couple. They are constantly trying to find that spark again, and effective communication is incredibly difficult for them both.

 

Pilot Episode Funding

Being grassroots means we seek to fund this project through collective community organization. It also means we, as representatives of our various diverse communities, control the entire production without the influence of corporate investors. We hope to raise $30,000 directly from the community to shoot the pilot for this series.

Your funds will help us:

  • Cast diverse talent that actually represents the rich diversity in our communities
  • Rent space and cover production related expenses
  • Compensate production team and cast members (many of whom have already volunteered many hours to this project!)

Identity-Conscious Casting

Coined by Lavina Jadhwani in 2014, Identity-Conscious casting goes beyond color-blind or color-conscious casting.  They quote, "because she believes identity contains multitudes and race is just one part of that." which is what we at Ebyssian Productions strive for -- roles written & casted for specific diverse and intersectional individuals. We believe that if the character in a story has a multitude of intersectional identifies (race, gender, sexuality, ability, age, etc.), then the actors and actresses that portray them should be as closely identical. This is to not only stay true to the story, but to allow those actors to bring their lived experience into the character. We acknowledge some wiggle room such as city of origin, political view, hobbies, careers, etc. but certain identities must match as close as possible with the characters we are portraying (and of course, strong acting skills). Race, gender, ethnicity, sexuality, ability, age, etc. are some of the significant factors we take into account during casting calls.

Read More:
https://howlround.com/identity-conscious-casting

Cultural/Advisory Board

This project is collaborative and community centered. We strive to make sure the communities depicted are respectfully represented. To ensure this, we formed the Cultural Advisory board and recruited members from the various communities to help guide the screenplay and production process. We will also be asking you, our funders, as well as community members to participate in the process as the pilot comes to life.

We are are not only open to feedback from the community.  This project is centered around community feedback and participation.  Look for updates from us on the various ways you can be involved.

 

Risks & Challenges

We recognize that funding a television series poses a variety of challenges. Grassroots isn't a typical way to fund a television series, but we are inspired  by the way underrepresented and marginalized communities have used the internet to challenge this lack of representation and add their own voices to a growing body of diverse projects. We are confident that a community funded project will be better able to retain it's Authenticity Through Humanity.

The community as a whole benefits from authentic depictions of underrepresented communities. Our project engages this by seeking to challenge stereotypes and power dynamics we can all relate to. 

 

Help Us Build More Representation

Representation matters! Any amount you can contribute is so greatly appreciated, but we recognize that not everyone has the means to contribute financially. Here are some other ways you can support the show:

  • Share this campaign with your network - Indiegogo makes it easy
  • Follow us on social media and spread the word
  • Help us pick a name for our show - use our poll: https://bit.ly/2PZPxsv
  • Contact us if you'd like to become a volunteer with the team

 

Thank you for your support!

Our ultimate goal is to develop a 6 episode season, starting with the pilot. Each episode will focus on the 'day in the life' of our main family, the Arbors. The Arbors are a bi-racial family with black and Filipino decent living in the city of Detroit.


Edith Arbor has an entrepreneurial spirit and hails from the Visayas region of the Philippines. She's juggling being a mother, an immigrant, and also trying to keep the family business a float with her husband and business partner, James. She moved to Michigan after marrying James and worked in a hospital as a nurse. Overtime, she and James decided to open a bubble tea shop and she soon left nursing to pursue her passion. She's extremely supportive of her children and wants them to peruse something they are passionate about. Sometimes, she struggles with relating to her children especially mental health wise.


James Arbor is an African-American veteran who fought in the Middle East and is currently dealing with undiagnosed PTSD and anxiety. Much of this is stemmed from both fighting for a country he is constantly alienated in and dealing with the 2020 pandemic.  He's also very hesitant with taking major financial risks with the family business as any entrepreneur would be. Originally working in the automotive industry, James decided to pursue his passion as well of opening a family run business and soon left the automotive field. James' fellow veteran friend, Traverse, constantly butt-heads on world views and beliefs, but manage to be civil. 

Louis Arbor is the oldest son. He works at a hospital in the business and finances department. Graduated with a technical writing degree from the University of Michigan, he's pursuing his passion, but ultimately wants to become a higher executive. Louis is also gay, but is not out and in a private secret relationship with his partner of a few years, Dr. Asa Coen. Louis also leans heavily conservative, providing more perspective as communities are not monoliths. His partner and Louis constantly debate over political matters, but are able to respect each other as well. 

Visaya Ann Arbor is the middle daughter. She is currently attending Wayne State University pursuing a degree in counseling and psychology. She works at the family shop in between school and on the weekends. She tries to understand people through her studies, but struggles oftentimes to empathize, which is key for her field. Studying and working so much has given her a lot of stress and anxiety and she struggles with self-acceptance, even though her grades are excellent. Visaya tries to remain neutral regarding politics, and tries focus on her studies, although she would lean left. 

Mindelina Arbor is the youngest child in the Arbor family. She is still attending high school and is not planning on attending college. Her passion is to be in media and dreams of being an influencer.  However, she deals with massive stage fright and oftentimes shuts down if people are watching her live. When she is alone, however, she feels confident and can express herself. Mindelina also has ADHD and juggling around high school, social media, and trying to keep up with the latest trends on TikTok, oftentimes shuts her down as well where every project is important, so no project is important, and this causes an endless cycle for her. Mindelina is also very vocal when it comes to racism and hatred. She's the opposite to her brother, Louis. 

They own a bubble tea shop in the fictional suburb of Verona Hills in the fictional county of Motorlake. Motorlake is located south of Oakland and Macomb, north of Wayne County and stretches from Livingston to Lake St. Clair. The county executive is Ruth Dovetail, a Native American woman with Odawa ancestry and the mayor of Verona Hills is a Muslim woman of South Asian heritage. There are several nearby suburbs, cities, and towns with the same name, as historically, many of these were part of the same town; Verona Woods, Verona Heights,  and Veronaopolis. 


Bahay Kubo Tea is the name of the Arbor's boba tea shop business. It has been struggling during the 2020 pandemic and the family is trying to make ends meet. The name Bahay Kubo is what the traditional homes in the Philippines are called, also known as nipa huts, so the bubble tea shop has become a 2nd home for the family and the community. Decorated with Detroit memorabilia and fusion of traditional Filipino decor, the shop welcomes the community in and has become a relatively known shop in the area over time.  One could tell this is family run as they proudly show their family photos on their walls behind the counter as well as other memories. The shop has been in business for about three years, but the pandemic hit their finances hard.
The show has many characters from a wide range of intersectional identities, classes, ethnicities, and backgrounds and will explore mental health as well as how the pandemic, rise of racial hate crimes, social media, politics, and technology have impacted many of the communities from the perspective of BIPoC and other marginalized communities.



Zahira is one of Visayas close friends and is also attending Wayne State University to peruse a career in psychology. Her dream is to be a therapist or a psychologist and to give back to her community in Dearborn. Zahira is Muslim. She's also a major activist and is on the board of multiple non-profit organizations. Zahira's belief is get involved, because that makes change. In her down time, she loves anime, video games, and absolutely loves to cosplay and is part of a few D&D campaigns. She's also a huge fan of the Ebyssian Elves, a fictional fantasy franchise that focuses on elves of color.  Zahira internally however, struggles with depression and anxiety being so busy. She also has a medical condition with her digestive track that causes her a great deal of stress. She struggles to say 'no' to opportunities, and can work herself into mental overload. 

Chinoden Gonzales-Mishimikinaak is a good friend to Louis and Asa. He is attending Oakland University and focusing on a career in political science. His dream is to be in politics and run for governor of Michigan, Senate, or Congress. He grew up in Detroit, and much of his culture and family are on the "rez". This has given him an internal identity crisis coming from two cultures of being Mexican American, as well as Native American, Ojibway. Chinoden struggles a lot with imposter syndrome and feels a disconnect to his heritage and culture.  Chinoden is also very much involved in political movements and oftentimes debates Louis. Louis, Asa, and Chinoden all met through the same dance crew, as this is how they handle much of their stress and anxiety.​

Dr. Asa Coen is Louis Arbor's boyfriend. They have been together for about a year. Asa comes from an Iberian Sephardic Jewish background. Asa grew up very poor with his parents in a small apartment.  When he was young, Asa came down with a serious health risk that pushed him into pursuing medical as a career choice. He loves to bake, but is terrible with following baking directions, and oftentimes experiments with weird concoctions that it makes Louis queasy. His dream was to open a pastry shop, but his life at the hospital has been so busy and rampant that he doesn’t have a lot of time to stop. With the rise of covid cases, he works even more hours which prolongs his deep passions. Asa also struggles with deep depression internally, although he rarely allows others to see it, other than Louis, and also struggles with ADHD. He takes a lot of this stress out in dance with his partner. He’s been nicknamed, “The Dancing Doctor” at his work.



Claire Houghton is the the wife of Traverse Houghton and mother to Dale Houghton. Claire and Traverse are old friends to the Arbors as Traverse and James fought in the Middle East together. Claire is a witty and open woman. Growing up, Claire marched in the 1960s for anti-war demonstrations and protests. She comes from a long line of suffragettes, hippies, and grew up middle class. Although Claire is disheartened by racism, she fails to see how systematic racism impacts her and her friends. Internally, she struggles with accepting her privilege and oftentimes alienates many of those she holds dear especially with her belief of 'not seeing color' as well as using her youth activism to prove herself. She's open to learning, but very much comes off as tone deaf.


Traverse Houghton is a very deep conservative Republican. He grew up in a very small town and was taught at a young age about American loyalty, values, and morals. Traverse has deeply internalized this over the years and strongly believes that success is solely dependent on one's own ambition, not the job of the government, and one's own failures is solely their own. When his son Dale came out as Trans-male, Traverse battled internally as well as externally to accept his son for who he is. Since Dale was a baby, Traverse cherished Dale as his dead name and identity Fern, his daughter. Today, Traverse encounters constant conflicts with Dale and others in the community, especially over politics. Traverse feels he doesn't know his child anymore. 

Dale Houghton is the adoptive son of Claire and Traverse. Dale was born in China and grew up in the suburbs. Internally, Dale battles being a trans-cultural and trans-national adoptee. He often has arguments with Louis as Louis still wants to call him by his dead name, Fern, and identities (she/her). Dale only within the last year or so has come out as trans-male. Despite the struggles, Dale put his heart and soul into social media as he has documented his story there and has become an influencer.  Dale his experience and his platform to empower others especially within the transgender communities, adoptee communities, Asian communities, and people of color. Although Dale comes off as put-together and empowered, Dale deals with significant depression and anxiety which causes Dale to go for days without updates on his social platforms, and finds confort in doing nothing.


 

Ichika and Xiong  Ichika was born and raised in southern California and met her husband when he was working in Los Angeles. Xiong is from Hawai'i and moved to Los Angeles to work. She tends to be quite a socialite and loves spending time with the communities. She's a third generation Japanese American. She doesn’t speak Japanese, and although raised in a Japanese family, she feels a disconnect to the motherland and her own culture. Ichika and Xiong opened a franchise bubble tea company and has grown pretty successful over the years. Their bubble tea shop has a very classy and upscale vibe with multiple private rooms for karaoke and banquet rooms for big parties. Xiong worked as an engineer for the automotive industry for many years until deciding to start the shop's franchise. While working for the automotive industry, Xiong and Ichika invested funds into a small shop and quickly grew until the big company today. Despite these successes, Xiong and Ichika are struggling with their marriage as they have slowly become more business partners than a loving couple. They are constantly trying to find that spark again, and effective communication is incredibly difficult for them both.
 
Pilot Episode Funding

Being grassroots means we seek to fund this project through collective community organization. It also means we, as representatives of our various diverse communities, control the entire production without the influence of corporate investors. We hope to raise $30,000 directly from the community to shoot the pilot for this series.
Your funds will help us:

Cast diverse talent that actually represents the rich diversity in our communities
Rent space and cover production related expenses
Compensate production team and cast members (many of whom have already volunteered many hours to this project!)

Identity-Conscious Casting
Coined by Lavina Jadhwani in 2014, Identity-Conscious casting goes beyond color-blind or color-conscious casting.  They quote, "because she believes identity contains multitudes and race is just one part of that." which is what we at Ebyssian Productions strive for -- roles written & casted for specific diverse and intersectional individuals. We believe that if the character in a story has a multitude of intersectional identifies (race, gender, sexuality, ability, age, etc.), then the actors and actresses that portray them should be as closely identical. This is to not only stay true to the story, but to allow those actors to bring their lived experience into the character. We acknowledge some wiggle room such as city of origin, political view, hobbies, careers, etc. but certain identities must match as close as possible with the characters we are portraying (and of course, strong acting skills). Race, gender, ethnicity, sexuality, ability, age, etc. are some of the significant factors we take into account during casting calls.
Read More:https://howlround.com/identity-conscious-casting

Cultural/Advisory Board
This project is collaborative and community centered. We strive to make sure the communities depicted are respectfully represented. To ensure this, we formed the Cultural Advisory board and recruited members from the various communities to help guide the screenplay and production process. We will also be asking you, our funders, as well as community members to participate in the process as the pilot comes to life.
We are are not only open to feedback from the community.  This project is centered around community feedback and participation.  Look for updates from us on the various ways you can be involved.


 
Risks & Challenges
We recognize that funding a television series poses a variety of challenges. Grassroots isn't a typical way to fund a television series, but we are inspired  by the way underrepresented and marginalized communities have used the internet to challenge this lack of representation and add their own voices to a growing body of diverse projects. We are confident that a community funded project will be better able to retain it's Authenticity Through Humanity.
The community as a whole benefits from authentic depictions of underrepresented communities. Our project engages this by seeking to challenge stereotypes and power dynamics we can all relate to. 
 
Help Us Build More Representation

Representation matters! Any amount you can contribute is so greatly appreciated, but we recognize that not everyone has the means to contribute financially. Here are some other ways you can support the show:

Share this campaign with your network - Indiegogo makes it easy
Follow us on social media and spread the word
Help us pick a name for our show - use our poll: https://bit.ly/2PZPxsv

Contact us if you'd like to become a volunteer with the team

 
Thank you for your support!

story:
LOG-LINE / SUMMARY

When a newly-minted Ph.D finds her Brooklyn neighborhood under siege by urban developers, this hip-hop loving millennial takes the fight straight to the Mid-Western  university that’s fueling the gentrification movement.  Little does she know the stunning twists and turns her life will take when Teaching While Black.

The pilot script for Teaching While Black was a 2020 Semi-Finalist for the international "WeScreenplay Diverse Voices" competition.  Help bring this important story to screens across the world by helping us reach our $5,000 goal!

 

CREATORS

Donnetrice Allison (Creator)

Donnetrice C. Allison, Ph.D serves as Professor of both Communication Studies and Africana Studies at Stockton University in Galloway, NJ.  Dr. Allison has been a Communication Studies scholar for more than two decades, and has published several articles and conference presentations on hip hop culture and media portrayals of African Americans.  Not only is Dr. Allison a published scholar, but she is also a creative writer, with a passion for bringing realistic Black life to the big and small screen. Her recent short screenplay, A Simple Walk, was a semifinalist in the 2021 Atlanta Film Festival Screenplay Competition.

Aaron Moss (Co-Creator)

Aaron Moss is an actor, director, and producer, who previously directed and produced the sitcom "Mixed Up" (Amazon) and the short-film “Blu & Sky” (pre-production), starring McKinley Belcher III.  As an actor, Aaron appeared in the 2014 Golden Globe winner for best movie, "American Hustle," and the box office hit, "The First Purge."  Aaron is a recipient of the 2011 Connecticut Critics Circle Award (Best Debut Performance) and was a 2018 ArtVoice nominee (Best Supporting Actor). 

 

WHAT YOUR FUNDING SUPPORTS

The funds from this campaign will be used to hire actors and crew to bring this story to life!

  • Hire Talent
  • To bring this story to life in a vivid and compelling way, we need to hire talented Actors and Crew.
  • Production Costs
    • Costumes, props, and equipment.
    • Meals and lodging for the cast and crew
  • Campaign Costs
    • Indiegogo Platform fees 

 

THE IMPACT

Since the national attention and support brought to the Black Lives Matter Movement, as a result of the senseless murder of George Floyd, several stories have emerged about widespread systemic racism in this country--revealing how every aspect of our society has been built on a racial hierarchy that places Black people at the bottom.  And while more and more Black creators are finding ways to tell those stories on the big and small screen, few have exposed the experiences of Black professors teaching at predominantly white institutions.  The recent headlines about Professor Nikole Hannah-Jones’ fight for tenure at The University of North Carolina--Chapel Hill is just one of many stories of racism and microaggressions faced by the mere 6 percent of Black faculty at public and private colleges and universities across the nation.  And among tenured professors in higher education, just 2.1 percent are Black women.  This story exposes that truth, through a satirical lens of one young Black woman’s journey into that world.  Given the current racial climate in this nation, it’s a timely story that many young professionals will be able to relate to as they navigate the challenge of being authentic in the workplace, while also trying to push for social justice and change.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Every contribution helps and no amount is too small! Not ready for a monetary donation? Please help get the word out by sharing this campaign with your friends, family, and social network.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT! AND THANKS FOR SHARING!

story:
Without your support, The Bech cannot exist. If we reach our goal, we'll create the best show we can, deliver you interactive content, and hand out some awesome perks while we're at it. Keep reading to find out more about the baddest beches in town!
 
Want to contribute, but not through IGG or don't have a credit card? No problem! There's an app for that! Just use the PayPal button, enter the amount you want, and let us know which perk you are going for! This button is live even after the campaign is closed!
 
 
Follow and share us on Instagram , Facebook , Twitter , Snapchat, and  Patreon!  #TheBechShow #Beches
 
You can also check out this awesome online store with all kinds of shirts and other fun items!

“Growing up, I looked up to real women. I didn’t go in for the hero worship, and I still don’t. Everybody has feet of clay.”

Lucy Lawless
 


The Idea:

The Bech goes back to the summer of 2015. With a BA in English Literature sitting in a drawer, Catarina, our creator, was finally ready to begin starting a journey to work for Disney, writing movies to inspire people all around the world. After months of researching, ideas for a web series began to become more enticing. Driven by a passion from her favorite show, Xena: Warrior Princess, the desire to create something meaningful manifested.

This unnamed project was being described as what would happen if an offspring of Orange is the New Black and The L Word had a child with a cross between How I Met Your Mother and Switched at Birth. In early 2017, the treatment and first season outline for The Bech were completed and looked over by several people. Months of feedback led to finally being ready to search for a crew. Alexis, who joined the team as the makeup artist, quickly became enamored by the premise. Soon, Alexis was named producer. Within weeks, Catarina and Alexis grew close and became the production team. With Catarina’s creativity and Alexis’ enthusiasm, they were able to pull together the start of a great cast and crew. Together, we are creating a web series with similar tones of Orange is the New Black and the feel of How I Met Your Mother. Many references can be found throughout the show to all of these shows - as well as several other works of fiction. The Bech is, first and foremost, a passion project meant to give representation and messages not often seen on television. 

 

 

Perks:

Notice something punny about our perks? All of them are named for an iconic LGBT film, show, or character.

From Sanvers to a post-apocalyptic future, we’ve thought up some plays on words. Are you up for a fun challenge? Tag us on Instagram @TheBechShow with a picture of the namesake and the name of the matching perk. The first person to correctly match the perk to the namesake will get tagged in a post on our page! Be sure to tag us and use #IndieGoGo and #Beches.

When choosing a wristband, you can choose from one of the following color options: black, rainbow, lesbian pride flag, bisexual pride flag, pansexual pride flag, transgender pride flag, or asexual pride flag.

All donations $55 or more will get your name in the scrolling credits at the end of the first season.

We will keep you up to date on when merchandise will be shipped out, and access to the first five episodes will be sent to the email you provide us.

Producer Level
Covering the budget of an entire episode will invite you to join us for the entire filming process of an episode of your choosing as the producer! In order of purchase, you will choose which one of the 25 episodes you want to produce. We will let you sit in on rehearsals - virtually or in person if you are local, send you exclusive footage, let you have some input on the script, speak with you over the phone, and dedicate the episode to you. Before the launch of the series premiere, you will receive the director’s script of the episode signed by the cast and crew. Additional perks: special place on donor list, social media shout outs, name in credits, we will follow you on social media, fan kit, access to exclusive video footage and spoilers, early access to entire season, early access to season two information, IMDB credit as a producer, invitation to our wrap party and screening.

Executive Producer Level
As our sincerest thank you for donating our entire post production budget, we will honor you on our website and social media as a co-executive producer. You will be flown out to Austin, Texas for a weekend as our ultimate, special guest. You won’t just be watching us. You will be co-directing! While you’re here, we’ll also throw fun events into the itinerary. Travel, lodging, and transportation for show-related events will be provided. As co-EP, you will have an open invitation to filmings, the wrap party, and the premiere screening. Additional perks: special place on donor list, social media shout outs, name in credits, we will follow you on social media, fan kit, access to exclusive video footage and spoilers, early access to ENTIRE SEASON, regular updates during filming, early access to season two information, IMDB credit as a director and co-executive producer.

If you donate $100 or more, we will send you a handwritten and signed thank you note with a unique fun fact from the show! Donate $1,000 or more, and you will receive a fun fact for each person that donated over $100! 
#BeTheChange.

 

Purpose:

There are two core themes to The Bech: diversity and young adult life.

Having a greatly diverse set of characters… Each of these characters come from various backgrounds that offer them a different perspective on similar situations that they face. While these characters may not always get along, and some simply do not like other, they will find themselves in tense discussions. Everyone has their own, unique personality that is conveyed through dialogue, mannerisms, reactions, actions, and music.

Portraying the lives of college students at different parts of their lives… Learning to be an adult and becoming independent while trying to stay afloat in college work is something every character struggles with in their own ways. There is no one size fits all method of dealing with the stresses of young adult life. They are at an age where respect is rarely given, but expectations and responsibilities are thrust upon them from all directions. Figuring out who they are and where they fit in is just one of the many things they will discover.


The recurring tones on the show:

Humorous/feel-good… Humor is a tool used by many of the characters to keep themselves from becoming overwhelmed - especially during enjoyable moments within the friend group. Characters tread lightly through uncomfortable situations by finding the balance between humor and drama to tackle difficult conversations. The show finds the balance between which topics can be portrayed through humor vs. drama. Inspiration for methods of portraying this greatly come from Orange is the New Black and How I Met Your Mother.

Overwhelmed… School, dating, work, financial aid… it can feel impossible to find some semblance of balance. For characters early in the coming out process or dealing with temperamental roommates, falling into a stressed state can be all too easy. The Fosters and Switched at Birth provided examples of how to handle young adults feeling in over their heads.

Passionate… Every character has something they are passionate about - some more than others. There will be several instances of some of the characters getting deeply passionate about a discussion, another person, or something going on in their lives. Although they may be close to someone, their passions do not always align with their friends. Part of growing up and growing close to others is learning how to respect that your loved ones may and will have different passions. This was an issue partially brought to attention in The L Word.

Compassionate...Through all of the moments, from feel-good to overwhelmed to passionate, these friends are there for each other. There is genuine love there. Several characters are the first to run in to comfort a friend, and many can empathize with what others are going through. This isn’t a group of friends that all identify the same way, but they have absolutely no difficulty sympathizing with one another. The Bech truly dives into complex relationships between friends - no matter their differences. A lesbian and straight woman can be close friends with no ulterior motives. A transgender woman and cisgender woman can live comfortably together without feeling even the slightest need to make their discussions circle around their identities. 
These characters are friends because of who they are… not what they are.


"And I tried to remember any case in the course of my reading where two women are represented as friends…They are now and then mothers and daughters. But almost without exception they are shown in their relation to men. It was strange to think that all the great women of fiction were, until Jane Austen’s day, not only seen by the other sex, but seen only in relation to the other sex. And how small a part of a woman’s life is that."

Virginia Woolf

Breakdown:

With this goal reached, we will be able to completely produce the first five episodes of the show. We have two seasons completely planned out, and the following two seasons are in the works! This isn't a temporary thing. We are in this for the long haul.

 


 

While our goal may seem like a random number, it's anything but. We've meticulously calculated the costs of everything from equipment to food to reimbursements to those awesome IndieGoGo fees. 

Our entire budget for the first season greatly goes toward our cast and crew. Without a talented, passionate, and dedicated team, it's truly difficult to make something great. 

We have filmed footage for our trailers that are currently in editing. All images and videos are from rehearsing for and filming the trailers. We begin filming this summer, so we're going full force on this IndieGoGo campaign to be able to bring you quality content.

Pilot:

Gabrielle has just moved to The Bech. We open with her exiting her apartment unit in a clearly frustrated state. As she’s leaving, she runs into Tiana. After the initial surprise of now living in the same apartment after not seeing each other much since they both started college, Gabrielle is introduced to Tiana’s roommate, Eliza. The three spend time in Tiana’s apartment, and Gabrielle and Eliza quickly bond by finding a shared interest in crazy Tiana stories. They each share a story before the scene changes as Gabrielle explains the tensions with her roommate. 

Danielle opens her front door in the opening of the scene. Gabrielle introduces herself as Danielle’s new roommate. Danielle is studying at the kitchen table, and Gabrielle enters the apartment with a box. The two women discuss decorating the main areas of the apartment. They come to an awkward agreement. Before Gabrielle leaves her apartment in a huff, she and Danielle get into an argument over use of the shared space. Danielle insists she can’t do any work if she can see Gabrielle.

Tiana and Eliza give Gabrielle fake, unhelpful advice - ranging from “cutting the bitch” to “seducing her.” Their fun ends when Tiana has to go to her shift at the front desk. 

Theme song: 

Walk away or see it through.
Pick what do I have to lose.
My whole world is turnin'.
Bridges burnin'.
It's time for my debut.

First Five Episodes:

"A Funny Thing, Luck "
Gabrielle moves into her new apartment and  is introduced and reintroduced to some of the residents of The Bech.

"My Friend is Gay"
Leia is having a difficult time adjusting and meets Tiana, who tells her that she has a lesbian friend that may be able to help her. 

"I See What You Mean" 
Leia mistakes Eliza for Gabrielle. Danielle finds out that her little sister will be coming to visit.

"It’s Not Awkward if You Laugh" 
Leia discovers the mistake she made over Eliza’s identity, and Gabrielle finds it amusing.

"Is it Prejudice or Personal?"
Tensions between Gabrielle and Danielle become obvious to more of The Bech friend group while they discuss different topics of diversity.


Characters:

GABRIELLE SANCHEZ is a second-year English student, feminine lesbian, and of Latin heritage. After being diagnosed with an Autism Spectrum Disorder in her first year of university, she underwent major changes in life and is now in a leadership role. More often than not, she does not realize someone is flirting with her until a friend points it out or she has someone’s tongue on her ear. She has three years to figure something out before student loans and real life begin - all while living with her near polar opposite.

LOIS ENTIN is in her third year of her communications degree. Determined to not let her depressive disorder be the leading factor in her life, she finds strength in helping animals. Growing up, she dated people of various genders, but could never find an identity she felt comfortable enough to claim. Lois cares more about being her best self than putting herself into a category. 

ALICE BETTON is cisgender and a third-year English and Theater double major who dreams of acting at the Shakespeare Globe Theatre. She is exceptionally outgoing and amicable, and is always convincing her roommates to throw parties. When she’s  not in party mode, she is in the mother role to the others. 

DANIELLE THOMAS, a white woman, is a third-year physics student from England. She’s studious, blunt, focused, and impatient. Her idea of fun is watching a documentary with a glass of red wine, and she doesn’t read anything with a plot. As a surrogate to family, she has become close to the professor for whom she is a TA, and she has not seen her real family since her first winter break in America. Coming from a background of nobility, she considers herself far too focused on her studies to worry about judging people or taking notice of the variety of identities that live around her. 

TIANA WILLIAMS is a second-year student and a straight, black woman studying biology on a pre-med track.  She’s full of qualities that are not generally seen together: intelligent, fun-loving, driven, heavy drinker, fiercely loyal friend, man-crazed, and studious. When in social settings, she lacks discretion with personal matters, often times sharing personal stories in great detail. While she’s always worked exceedingly hard in school, Tiana now has med-school applications on the horizon amongst all of her responsibilities at The Bech, but she sometimes can’t stop thinking about sex.

ELIZA SIMMONS, a woman of color, is a straight, first-year student studying student affairs. Her love for alcohol is rivaled only by her love for food. 

LEIA CORINTH, a bisexual woman, is a first-year Radio-Television-Film student from Alaska with two dads. 

SAMMIE SMITH is a more masculinely-dressed lesbian, third-year history major, and student athlete that was outed during an incident with another team. 

ALEXANDER McALLEN, a gay third-year journalism student, is on the football team with a full ride that sees his sexuality as merely a small part of who he is.

JORDAN TAMLIN is Alice's cousin and a transgender woman studying engineering, who enjoys joking about the odds of her and her three roommates being women loving women.

JAKE WATERS is an aromantic sophomore, studying astrophysics. Along with a budding friendship with Danielle, he has connections to several other characters. 

RENEE THOMAS, Danielle’s little sister, is in her senior year of high school. Her quick wit and sarcastic sense of humor make her stand out from her sister. 

LANE RAY is pansexual and a fourth-year history major. His goofy personality is accompanied by a love for comics, sci-fi, and superheroes.

KATIE GOMEZ, a second-year business student, transfers to the school for the second semester. She keeps to herself, and everyone begins to wonder many things about her. 


The Current Team:

Catarina Elibeth - creator, executive producer, writer, director
Robert Lloyd Moore  - director of photography
Siegen Bretzke  - composer, production sound mixer
Jacob Stone - cinematographer
Alexis Skidmore - associate producer
Nicolette Sciore Koalewski  - production assistant
Christopher Noia  - recording engineer, boom operator
Carol Camp  - colorist
Meredith Ashley - badass beta and legal consultant
CJ "jedifighterpilot2727" Waterford - writer
Dylan Keitz-Playford  - writer
Harris Baumann  - writer in training

Katy Atkinson...................................................Gabrielle Sanchez
Katusha Robert................................................Lois Entin
Rachel Pallante ................................................Alice Betton
Anitra Whitfield ................................................Tiana Williams
Catherine Rivas  ...............................................Eliza Simmons
Tessa Goodnight ..............................................Leia Corinth
Franziska Dietl ..................................................Sammie Smith
Rory Mitchell.....................................................Alexander McAllen
Hristiana Soula.................................................Jordan Tamlin
Doug Atkins ......................................................Jake Waters
Ian Geyer............................................................Lane Ray

IMDB Page 



Thank you:

This passion project is truly designed to make a difference. We have so many identities being represented in this show, and immense, constant research has been and will continue to be put into creating it.  The Bech is for you. It's for us. It's for everyone that has ever wanted to see someone like them on TV. It's for those of us who want something different. There's something for everyone, and we cannot make it happen without you.


We cannot thank you enough for contributing to make this dream a reality. Our team will be highly active on social media before, during, and after the entire filming process. Along with the perks we have to offer, every person that donates will get an email from us with our sincerest gratitude. With every milestone we pass, we will share everything we feel and accomplish with you.
story_txt:
Without your support, The Bech cannot exist. If we reach our goal, we'll create the best show we can, deliver you interactive content, and hand out some awesome perks while we're at it. Keep reading to find out more about the baddest beches in town! Want to contribute, but not through IGG or don't have a credit card? No problem! There's an app for that! Just use the PayPal button, enter the amount you want, and let us know which perk you are going for! This button is live even after the campaign is closed!  Follow and share us on Instagram , Facebook , Twitter , Snapchat, and  Patreon!  #TheBechShow #Beches You can also check out this awesome online store with all kinds of shirts and other fun items!


“Growing up, I looked up to real women. I didn’t go in for the hero worship, and I still don’t. Everybody has feet of clay.”Lucy Lawless
 
The Idea:The Bech goes back to the summer of 2015. With a BA in English Literature sitting in a drawer, Catarina, our creator, was finally ready to begin starting a journey to work for Disney, writing movies to inspire people all around the world. After months of researching, ideas for a web series began to become more enticing. Driven by a passion from her favorite show, Xena: Warrior Princess, the desire to create something meaningful manifested.This unnamed project was being described as what would happen if an offspring of Orange is the New Black and The L Word had a child with a cross between How I Met Your Mother and Switched at Birth. In early 2017, the treatment and first season outline for The Bech were completed and looked over by several people. Months of feedback led to finally being ready to search for a crew. Alexis, who joined the team as the makeup artist, quickly became enamored by the premise. Soon, Alexis was named producer. Within weeks, Catarina and Alexis grew close and became the production team. With Catarina’s creativity and Alexis’ enthusiasm, they were able to pull together the start of a great cast and crew. Together, we are creating a web series with similar tones of Orange is the New Black and the feel of How I Met Your Mother. Many references can be found throughout the show to all of these shows - as well as several other works of fiction. The Bech is, first and foremost, a passion project meant to give representation and messages not often seen on television. 
 
 
Perks:
Notice something punny about our perks? All of them are named for an iconic LGBT film, show, or character.
From Sanvers to a post-apocalyptic future, we’ve thought up some plays on words. Are you up for a fun challenge? Tag us on Instagram @TheBechShow with a picture of the namesake and the name of the matching perk. The first person to correctly match the perk to the namesake will get tagged in a post on our page! Be sure to tag us and use #IndieGoGo and #Beches.
When choosing a wristband, you can choose from one of the following color options: black, rainbow, lesbian pride flag, bisexual pride flag, pansexual pride flag, transgender pride flag, or asexual pride flag.
All donations $55 or more will get your name in the scrolling credits at the end of the first season.We will keep you up to date on when merchandise will be shipped out, and access to the first five episodes will be sent to the email you provide us.Producer LevelCovering the budget of an entire episode will invite you to join us for the entire filming process of an episode of your choosing as the producer! In order of purchase, you will choose which one of the 25 episodes you want to produce. We will let you sit in on rehearsals - virtually or in person if you are local, send you exclusive footage, let you have some input on the script, speak with you over the phone, and dedicate the episode to you. Before the launch of the series premiere, you will receive the director’s script of the episode signed by the cast and crew. Additional perks: special place on donor list, social media shout outs, name in credits, we will follow you on social media, fan kit, access to exclusive video footage and spoilers, early access to entire season, early access to season two information, IMDB credit as a producer, invitation to our wrap party and screening.Executive Producer LevelAs our sincerest thank you for donating our entire post production budget, we will honor you on our website and social media as a co-executive producer. You will be flown out to Austin, Texas for a weekend as our ultimate, special guest. You won’t just be watching us. You will be co-directing! While you’re here, we’ll also throw fun events into the itinerary. Travel, lodging, and transportation for show-related events will be provided. As co-EP, you will have an open invitation to filmings, the wrap party, and the premiere screening. Additional perks: special place on donor list, social media shout outs, name in credits, we will follow you on social media, fan kit, access to exclusive video footage and spoilers, early access to ENTIRE SEASON, regular updates during filming, early access to season two information, IMDB credit as a director and co-executive producer.If you donate $100 or more, we will send you a handwritten and signed thank you note with a unique fun fact from the show! Donate $1,000 or more, and you will receive a fun fact for each person that donated over $100! #BeTheChange.


 

Purpose:There are two core themes to The Bech: diversity and young adult life.Having a greatly diverse set of characters… Each of these characters come from various backgrounds that offer them a different perspective on similar situations that they face. While these characters may not always get along, and some simply do not like other, they will find themselves in tense discussions. Everyone has their own, unique personality that is conveyed through dialogue, mannerisms, reactions, actions, and music.Portraying the lives of college students at different parts of their lives… Learning to be an adult and becoming independent while trying to stay afloat in college work is something every character struggles with in their own ways. There is no one size fits all method of dealing with the stresses of young adult life. They are at an age where respect is rarely given, but expectations and responsibilities are thrust upon them from all directions. Figuring out who they are and where they fit in is just one of the many things they will discover.The recurring tones on the show:Humorous/feel-good… Humor is a tool used by many of the characters to keep themselves from becoming overwhelmed - especially during enjoyable moments within the friend group. Characters tread lightly through uncomfortable situations by finding the balance between humor and drama to tackle difficult conversations. The show finds the balance between which topics can be portrayed through humor vs. drama. Inspiration for methods of portraying this greatly come from Orange is the New Black and How I Met Your Mother.
Overwhelmed… School, dating, work, financial aid… it can feel impossible to find some semblance of balance. For characters early in the coming out process or dealing with temperamental roommates, falling into a stressed state can be all too easy. The Fosters and Switched at Birth provided examples of how to handle young adults feeling in over their heads.
Passionate… Every character has something they are passionate about - some more than others. There will be several instances of some of the characters getting deeply passionate about a discussion, another person, or something going on in their lives. Although they may be close to someone, their passions do not always align with their friends. Part of growing up and growing close to others is learning how to respect that your loved ones may and will have different passions. This was an issue partially brought to attention in The L Word.
Compassionate...Through all of the moments, from feel-good to overwhelmed to passionate, these friends are there for each other. There is genuine love there. Several characters are the first to run in to comfort a friend, and many can empathize with what others are going through. This isn’t a group of friends that all identify the same way, but they have absolutely no difficulty sympathizing with one another. The Bech truly dives into complex relationships between friends - no matter their differences. A lesbian and straight woman can be close friends with no ulterior motives. A transgender woman and cisgender woman can live comfortably together without feeling even the slightest need to make their discussions circle around their identities. These characters are friends because of who they are… not what they are."And I tried to remember any case in the course of my reading where two women are represented as friends…They are now and then mothers and daughters. But almost without exception they are shown in their relation to men. It was strange to think that all the great women of fiction were, until Jane Austen’s day, not only seen by the other sex, but seen only in relation to the other sex. And how small a part of a woman’s life is that."Virginia WoolfBreakdown:With this goal reached, we will be able to completely produce the first five episodes of the show. We have two seasons completely planned out, and the following two seasons are in the works! This isn't a temporary thing. We are in this for the long haul.
 
 
While our goal may seem like a random number, it's anything but. We've meticulously calculated the costs of everything from equipment to food to reimbursements to those awesome IndieGoGo fees. 
Our entire budget for the first season greatly goes toward our cast and crew. Without a talented, passionate, and dedicated team, it's truly difficult to make something great. We have filmed footage for our trailers that are currently in editing. All images and videos are from rehearsing for and filming the trailers. We begin filming this summer, so we're going full force on this IndieGoGo campaign to be able to bring you quality content.Pilot:Gabrielle has just moved to The Bech. We open with her exiting her apartment unit in a clearly frustrated state. As she’s leaving, she runs into Tiana. After the initial surprise of now living in the same apartment after not seeing each other much since they both started college, Gabrielle is introduced to Tiana’s roommate, Eliza. The three spend time in Tiana’s apartment, and Gabrielle and Eliza quickly bond by finding a shared interest in crazy Tiana stories. They each share a story before the scene changes as Gabrielle explains the tensions with her roommate. Danielle opens her front door in the opening of the scene. Gabrielle introduces herself as Danielle’s new roommate. Danielle is studying at the kitchen table, and Gabrielle enters the apartment with a box. The two women discuss decorating the main areas of the apartment. They come to an awkward agreement. Before Gabrielle leaves her apartment in a huff, she and Danielle get into an argument over use of the shared space. Danielle insists she can’t do any work if she can see Gabrielle.Tiana and Eliza give Gabrielle fake, unhelpful advice - ranging from “cutting the bitch” to “seducing her.” Their fun ends when Tiana has to go to her shift at the front desk. Theme song: Walk away or see it through.Pick what do I have to lose.My whole world is turnin'.Bridges burnin'.It's time for my debut.First Five Episodes:"A Funny Thing, Luck "Gabrielle moves into her new apartment and  is introduced and reintroduced to some of the residents of The Bech."My Friend is Gay"Leia is having a difficult time adjusting and meets Tiana, who tells her that she has a lesbian friend that may be able to help her. "I See What You Mean" Leia mistakes Eliza for Gabrielle. Danielle finds out that her little sister will be coming to visit."It’s Not Awkward if You Laugh" Leia discovers the mistake she made over Eliza’s identity, and Gabrielle finds it amusing."Is it Prejudice or Personal?"Tensions between Gabrielle and Danielle become obvious to more of The Bech friend group while they discuss different topics of diversity.Characters:GABRIELLE SANCHEZ is a second-year English student, feminine lesbian, and of Latin heritage. After being diagnosed with an Autism Spectrum Disorder in her first year of university, she underwent major changes in life and is now in a leadership role. More often than not, she does not realize someone is flirting with her until a friend points it out or she has someone’s tongue on her ear. She has three years to figure something out before student loans and real life begin - all while living with her near polar opposite.
LOIS ENTIN is in her third year of her communications degree. Determined to not let her depressive disorder be the leading factor in her life, she finds strength in helping animals. Growing up, she dated people of various genders, but could never find an identity she felt comfortable enough to claim. Lois cares more about being her best self than putting herself into a category. 
ALICE BETTON is cisgender and a third-year English and Theater double major who dreams of acting at the Shakespeare Globe Theatre. She is exceptionally outgoing and amicable, and is always convincing her roommates to throw parties. When she’s  not in party mode, she is in the mother role to the others. 
DANIELLE THOMAS, a white woman, is a third-year physics student from England. She’s studious, blunt, focused, and impatient. Her idea of fun is watching a documentary with a glass of red wine, and she doesn’t read anything with a plot. As a surrogate to family, she has become close to the professor for whom she is a TA, and she has not seen her real family since her first winter break in America. Coming from a background of nobility, she considers herself far too focused on her studies to worry about judging people or taking notice of the variety of identities that live around her. 
TIANA WILLIAMS is a second-year student and a straight, black woman studying biology on a pre-med track.  She’s full of qualities that are not generally seen together: intelligent, fun-loving, driven, heavy drinker, fiercely loyal friend, man-crazed, and studious. When in social settings, she lacks discretion with personal matters, often times sharing personal stories in great detail. While she’s always worked exceedingly hard in school, Tiana now has med-school applications on the horizon amongst all of her responsibilities at The Bech, but she sometimes can’t stop thinking about sex.
ELIZA SIMMONS, a woman of color, is a straight, first-year student studying student affairs. Her love for alcohol is rivaled only by her love for food.

ALEXANDER McALLEN, a gay third-year journalism student, is on the football team with a full ride that sees his sexuality as merely a small part of who he is.
JORDAN TAMLIN is Alice's cousin and a transgender woman studying engineering, who enjoys joking about the odds of her and her three roommates being women loving women.
JAKE WATERS is an aromantic sophomore, studying astrophysics. Along with a budding friendship with Danielle, he has connections to several other characters. 
RENEE THOMAS, Danielle’s little sister, is in her senior year of high school. Her quick wit and sarcastic sense of humor make her stand out from her sister. 
LANE RAY is pansexual and a fourth-year history major. His goofy personality is accompanied by a love for comics, sci-fi, and superheroes.
KATIE GOMEZ, a second-year business student, transfers to the school for the second semester. She keeps to herself, and everyone begins to wonder many things about her.

We have so many identities being represented in this show, and immense, constant research has been and will continue to be put into creating it.  The Bech is for you. It's for us. It's for everyone that has ever wanted to see someone like them on TV. It's for those of us who want something different. There's something for everyone, and we cannot make it happen without you.

story:
What is Black Fist Immortal?

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • I have estimated that we need about $30,000 to get this all of the ground. As the know film making is extremely expensive and this is a very low number for what we are trying to achieve. This money will go towards better a/v equipment, location security and insurance, crew fees, rental fees, licensing, trademarks and copyright.
  • We will be offering original artwork, episode shout outs, t-shirts, free access to upcoming episodes, free access to upcoming projects
  • If we do not reach the goal the fund will be allotted to equipment advertising and the crew for over a year of dedicated work

    Creating this film has been a monumental accomplishment in my life. I started as a student, became a veteran, and ultimately settled on being an artist. Finishing this project will give me the boost I need to get my production company off the ground so we can bring our first series; BlackFist Immortal to everyone. I want to share martial arts values with a new generation, and I want to encourage local artists to further their own careers. Your donations will allow me to help many people that may not otherwise have that chance.

     

    A story centered around a third generation Martial Arts master has taken me six years to develop. With this series, our goal is to establish his world and the individuals he meets, with the hope that investors like yourselves can relate to the culture and the characters.

     

    - My name is Ed Bridges, and I have studied various martial arts styles for over 26 years. I am a theater-trained thespian, and a veteran of the US Navy OIF-OEF 2001-2005 Hon. Discharge. In the Navy I was a photographer during aerial combat operations. When I returned home, I studied film production at the Art Institute of Phoenix from 2011-2013.

    - This is my dream finally becoming a reality. I built this team and crew to cultivate this dream, and I have established connections with quality talent and artists from the city of Phoenix for our productions. This has provided opportunities for several local artists that were passionate about achieving their own dreams.

    - I have already created a pilot episode for the series out of my own pocket. Your donations will not only give us the ability to finish this story arc, but also begin to develop new projects at a higher level and quality.

     

Let's break it down into more details:

 

- I have estimated that we need about $30,000 to get this off the ground. As you know, making films, even independent films can be extremely expensive. Your donations will go towards better audio and video equipment, securing locations, insurance, crew fees, rental fees, licensing, trademarks and copyright.

- We will be offering perks such as original artwork, episode shout-outs, apparel, free access to upcoming episodes, and free access to upcoming projects.

- If we're unable to reach the goal, the funds will be allotted to equipment, advertising, and the crew for more than a year of dedicated work.

 

- Your contribution will create a new platform of media. My production company will produce music, play films, videos, and shows.

- I have already completed the pilot so you can see the show just as we intended it. I made the entire pilot with my personal funds to communicate that I finish everything I start, and that the project was worth my time and effort. The episode cost over $6,000.

- Your contribution will support over 100 hours of training, planning, and production.

 

Risks & Challenges

- My BlackFist production videos each receive over 1,000 views within a day.

- I plan to personally promote this campaign over all available media outlets, groups, and community pages

 

Other Ways You Can Help

- Share our link and videos with friends, and fans of martial arts. Together, we would be a major boost for the team!

- Use the available share tools on this page to send to your friends in other states and countries.
